message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described on the left arm suggest an injury to the brachial plexus. In this case, the most likely nerve roots affected are C5 and C6, which innervate the muscles responsible for shoulder abduction, elbow flexion, and wrist extension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented by the baby indicate a brachial plexus injury, specifically Erb's palsy. This injury is caused by damage to the C5 and C6 nerve roots. The other options do not include these nerve roots and are less likely to be the cause of the injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the infant might have suffered a brachial plexus injury during delivery. The fact that the right arm functions normally and the left arm is pronated and medially rotated suggests an injury to the C5 and C6 nerve roots, which are located in the upper part of the brachial plexus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the baby's arm suggests an injury to the brachial plexus, specifically the upper trunk involving C5 and C6 nerve roots. The other options do not involve the nerve roots that innervate the affected muscles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests Erb's palsy, which is caused by injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, specifically the C5 and C6 nerve roots. Option (B) is the correct answer. The other options involve nerve roots that are not specifically associated with Erb's palsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with Erb-Duchenne palsy, which is caused by damage to the C5-C6 nerve roots. Option B is the correct choice. C4-C5 damage will cause a different set of symptoms, while C6-C7 damage will cause a different type of palsy called Klumpke's palsy. C8-T1 damage is less common and typically presents with hand weakness rather than arm weakness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a brachial plexus injury, specifically involving the upper trunk. The upper trunk is formed by the union of the C5 and C6 roots, so the most likely answer is (B) C5 and C6.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant has signs of Erb's palsy, which is caused by damage to the brachial plexus. The most commonly injured nerve roots in this condition are C5 and C6.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with Erb’s palsy, which is caused by traction injury to the brachial plexus during delivery. This injury most commonly involves the C5 and C6 nerve roots. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The baby’s left arm being pronated and medially rotated suggests a brachial plexus injury, specifically affecting the upper trunk or C5 and C6 nerve roots. C4 does not participate in the brachial plexus, C7 and T1 are lower in the plexus and have different muscle innervations.
